name: Tamagoyaki (Japanese Rolled Omelette) ‚Äî Dashimaki Tamago
description: Lightly sweet yet savory, Tamagoyaki (Japanese Rolled Omelette) is flavored with dashi stock and makes a delightful Japanese breakfast or side dish for your bento lunches. Primarily enjoyed in the Kansai (Osaka) region, this tamagoyaki is a dashi-forward Dashimaki Tamago.

video.name: How To Make Tamagoyaki (Recipe) ÁéâÂ≠êÁÑº„Åç„ÅÆ‰Ωú„ÇäÊñπ Ôºà„É¨„Ç∑„ÉîÔºâ
video.description:
Lightly sweet yet savory, Tamagoyaki (Japanese Rolled Omelette) is flavored with dashi stock and makes a delightful Japanese breakfast or side dish for your bento lunches. Tamagoyaki is Japanese rolled omelette with dashi and soy sauce, enjoyed during Japanese breakfast or as a bento item. 
RECIPE ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/tamagoyaki-japanese-rolled-omelette/

Ingredients:
3 large eggs
2 Tbsp. cooking oil (vegetable or canola)
1¬Ω sheet nori (optional)
1" (2.5 cm) green part of daikon radish (it's sweeter than white part)
Soy sauce

Seasonings
3 Tbsp. dashi (Recipe: http://bit.ly/HowToMakeDashiVideo)
2 tsp. sugar
1 tsp. soy sauce
1 tsp. mirin
2 pinches of salt

What you will need:
Tamagoyaki frying pan (or a around 9" or 10" non-stick frying pan)
Long cooking chopsticks
Bamboo mat

#tamagoyaki #japanesefood #omelette 

Instructions ‚ñ∂ https://www.justonecookbook.com/tamagoyaki-japanese-rolled-omelette/

Let's cook EASY + AUTHENTIC Japanese recipes at home!
Konnichiwa! I'm Nami, the creator of the Just One Cookbook website and cooking blog. I am glad that you are here with me. Here and on JustOneCookbook.com, you can find over 1,200 recipes, cooking tips, step-by-step instructions, ingredients, and shopping guides focused on Japanese cuisine.

I'm a native Japanese, born and raised in Yokohama, Japan, and now live in San Francisco, California, with my husband Mr. JOC, two high school kids, and a dog named Miso. I also wrote three Japanese cookbooks, where I share popular recipes like Oyakodon, Tamagoyaki, Chawanmushi, Sushi, Okonomiyaki, Mochi Ice Cream, Gyoza, Ramen, and more!

recipeIngredient: 3  large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
1 tsp soy sauce ((use GF soy sauce for gluten-free))
1¬Ω sheets nori (dried laver seaweed) ((optional; see Method 2 below))
soy sauce ((use GF soy sauce for gluten-free))

recipeInstructions.text: Before we start... Among all the types of tamagoyaki, this is the most challenging to make as the egg mixture is very watery. If you're new to tamagoyaki making, start practicing with my 3-Ingredient Simple Tamagoyaki recipe without dashi.Gather all the ingredients.
recipeInstructions.name: Before we start... Among all the types of tamagoyaki, this is the most challenging to make as the egg mixture is very watery. If you're new to tamagoyaki making, start practicing with my 3-Ingredient Simple Tamagoyaki recipe without dashi.Gather all the ingredients.

recipeInstructions.text: In a bowl, gently whisk 3 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell). It‚Äòs best to ‚Äúcut‚Äú the eggs with chopsticks in a zig-zag motion; do not overmix.
recipeInstructions.name: In a bowl, gently whisk 3 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell). It‚Äòs best to ‚Äúcut‚Äú the eggs with chopsticks in a zig-zag motion; do not overmix.

recipeInstructions.text: In another bowl, combine the seasonings: 3 Tbsp dashi (Japanese soup stock), 2 tsp sugar, 1 tsp soy sauce, 1 tsp mirin, and 2 pinches Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Mix well.
recipeInstructions.name: In another bowl, combine the seasonings: 3 Tbsp dashi (Japanese soup stock), 2 tsp sugar, 1 tsp soy sauce, 1 tsp mirin, and 2 pinches Diamond Crystal kosher salt. Mix well.

recipeInstructions.text: Pour the seasonings mixture into the eggs and whisk gently to combine. Then, pour the mixture into a measuring cup with a spout and handle so that it‚Äòll be easier to pour into the frying pan. Next, I‚Äòll show you how to make your omelette in either a tamagoyaki pan or a round frying pan.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour the seasonings mixture into the eggs and whisk gently to combine. Then, pour the mixture into a measuring cup with a spout and handle so that it‚Äòll be easier to pour into the frying pan. Next, I‚Äòll show you how to make your omelette in either a tamagoyaki pan or a round frying pan.
(Method 1) To Cook in a Tamagoyaki Pan

itemListElement.text: Heat the pan over medium heat. Then, dip a folded paper towel in 2 Tbsp neutral oil and apply a thin layer of oil to the pan. To check if the pan is hot enough, put a drop of the egg mixture in the pan. When you hear a sizzling sound, the pan is ready.
itemListElement.name: Heat the pan over medium heat. Then, dip a folded paper towel in 2 Tbsp neutral oil and apply a thin layer of oil to the pan. To check if the pan is hot enough, put a drop of the egg mixture in the pan. When you hear a sizzling sound, the pan is ready.

itemListElement.text: Pour a thin layer of the egg mixture into the pan, quickly tilting the pan so that the egg mixture coats the entire cooking surface.
itemListElement.name: Pour a thin layer of the egg mixture into the pan, quickly tilting the pan so that the egg mixture coats the entire cooking surface.

itemListElement.text: Poke any air bubbles to release the air. After the bottom of the egg has set but is still soft on top, start rolling the egg into a log shape from one side to the other, starting from the far side of the pan and rolling toward the pan handle.
itemListElement.name: Poke any air bubbles to release the air. After the bottom of the egg has set but is still soft on top, start rolling the egg into a log shape from one side to the other, starting from the far side of the pan and rolling toward the pan handle.

itemListElement.text: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll, and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette.
itemListElement.name: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll, and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette.

itemListElement.text: Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.
itemListElement.name: Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.

itemListElement.text: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other.
itemListElement.name: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other.

itemListElement.text: Move the rolled omelette to the side where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette.
itemListElement.name: Move the rolled omelette to the side where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette.

itemListElement.text: Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.
itemListElement.name: Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.

itemListElement.text: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other.
itemListElement.name: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other.

itemListElement.text: Repeat the process. This is now the third round.
itemListElement.name: Repeat the process. This is now the third round.

itemListElement.text: This is the fourth round. Pour in more egg mixture and make sure it thinly coats the bottom of the pan, including under the rolled omelette.
itemListElement.name: This is the fourth round. Pour in more egg mixture and make sure it thinly coats the bottom of the pan, including under the rolled omelette.

itemListElement.text: Continue rolling it into a log shape. Tip: Control the temperature of the pan by lifting the frying pan rather than adjusting the stove heat. If the heat is too weak, the egg will stick to the frying pan, so be careful.
itemListElement.name: Continue rolling it into a log shape. Tip: Control the temperature of the pan by lifting the frying pan rather than adjusting the stove heat. If the heat is too weak, the egg will stick to the frying pan, so be careful.

itemListElement.text: This is the fifth round.
itemListElement.name: This is the fifth round.

itemListElement.text: This is the sixth and final round.
itemListElement.name: This is the sixth and final round.

itemListElement.text: You can brown the omelette a little bit.
itemListElement.name: You can brown the omelette a little bit.

itemListElement.text: Remove it from the pan and place the omelette on a bamboo sushi mat. While it‚Äôs still hot, roll up the omelette in the bamboo mat to help set its shape. Let it stand for 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Remove it from the pan and place the omelette on a bamboo sushi mat. While it‚Äôs still hot, roll up the omelette in the bamboo mat to help set its shape. Let it stand for 5 minutes.

recipeInstructions.name: (Method 2) To Cook in a Round Frying Pan

itemListElement.text: Heat the pan over medium heat. Then, dip a folded paper towel in 2 Tbsp neutral oil and apply a thin layer of oil to the pan. To check if the pan is hot enough, put a drop of the egg mixture in the pan. When you hear a sizzling sound, the pan is ready. Then, pour a thin layer of the egg mixture into the pan, quickly tilting the pan so that the egg mixture coats the entire cooking surface.
itemListElement.name: Heat the pan over medium heat. Then, dip a folded paper towel in 2 Tbsp neutral oil and apply a thin layer of oil to the pan. To check if the pan is hot enough, put a drop of the egg mixture in the pan. When you hear a sizzling sound, the pan is ready. Then, pour a thin layer of the egg mixture into the pan, quickly tilting the pan so that the egg mixture coats the entire cooking surface.

itemListElement.text: Poke any air bubbles to release the air. After the bottom of the egg has set but is still soft on top, start rolling the egg into a log shape from one side to the other, starting from the far side of the pan and rolling toward the pan handle. Here, I added ¬Ω sheet of nori (optional) to my omelette and then rolled.
itemListElement.name: Poke any air bubbles to release the air. After the bottom of the egg has set but is still soft on top, start rolling the egg into a log shape from one side to the other, starting from the far side of the pan and rolling toward the pan handle. Here, I added ¬Ω sheet of nori (optional) to my omelette and then rolled.

itemListElement.text: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette. Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.
itemListElement.name: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette. Pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.

itemListElement.text: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other. This is optional, but I placed another layer of ¬Ω nori sheet on top before rolling.
itemListElement.name: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other. This is optional, but I placed another layer of ¬Ω nori sheet on top before rolling.

itemListElement.text: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette. Then pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.
itemListElement.name: Move the rolled omelette to the far side of the pan where you started to roll and apply more oil to the pan with a paper towel, even under the omelette. Then pour in a thin layer of the egg mixture to just cover the bottom of the pan again. Make sure to lift the omelette to spread the mixture underneath.

itemListElement.text: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other. I placed another ¬Ω sheet of nori here before rolling. Continue until you‚Äôve used all of the egg mixture.
itemListElement.name: When the new layer of egg has set and is still soft on top, start rolling it from one side to the other. I placed another ¬Ω sheet of nori here before rolling. Continue until you‚Äôve used all of the egg mixture.

itemListElement.text: Remove it from the pan and place the omelette on a bamboo sushi mat. While it‚Äôs still hot, roll up the omelette in the bamboo mat to help set its shape. Let it stand for 5 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Remove it from the pan and place the omelette on a bamboo sushi mat. While it‚Äôs still hot, roll up the omelette in the bamboo mat to help set its shape. Let it stand for 5 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Slice the omelette into ¬Ω-inch (1-cm) pieces.
itemListElement.name: Slice the omelette into ¬Ω-inch (1-cm) pieces.

itemListElement.text: Peel and grate 3 oz daikon radish. Gently squeeze the water out and place in a small dish or bowl. Pour soy sauce over the grated daikon and serve on the side with the Tamagoyaki.
itemListElement.name: Peel and grate 3 oz daikon radish. Gently squeeze the water out and place in a small dish or bowl. Pour soy sauce over the grated daikon and serve on the side with the Tamagoyaki.

itemListElement.text: You can put the Tamagoyaki in an airtight container and store in the freezer for up to 2 weeks. Defrost overnight in the refrigerator or microwave.
itemListElement.name: You can put the Tamagoyaki in an airtight container and store in the freezer for up to 2 weeks. Defrost overnight in the refrigerator or microwave.

review.reviewBody: I don‚Äôt understand‚Ä¶ 3 tbsp of dashi is way way too much for 3 eggs. I knew this but followed the recipe anyway and it was inedible‚Ä¶ is it supposed to be 3 tsp???

I‚Äôve thought to try making tamagoyaki in a real tamagoyaki pan. I finally bought the last week and this evening I tried making my first tamagoyaki. It‚Äôs not as difficult as i‚Äôd feared! I didn‚Äôt have any dashi, so I need to get some for next time. It turned out just fine, though not as nice as yours. Hanks for the inspiration!
This is so fun to make in a tamagoyaki pan! I love experimenting with it too, the recipe is very forgiving üòä

I've been wanting to make this ever since I watched Midnight Diner. I made it today for the first time and it turned out great! I didn't have dashi, so I subbed 1 t miso paste in 3 T water. It was delicious! This might be my new go-to breakfast.

I really appreciate you having a video showing how to use this pan. I just came back from Tokyo, and I bought a copper, Kansai style small pan. You mention it is the best, but I do not see you using it. Also, you mention atsuyaki tamago, and that it is easier to make. However, there is no information on how to make it. It seems like it would be a good place to start with a new pan!

I have chickens, and I would love for you to provide many more egg based recipes. Also, one of the hotels I stayed at in Tokyo had the most amazingly healthy breakfast, It had the same basics, as you describe. in your traditional breakfast. Miso soup is a wonderful addition to breakfast! But it also had various steamed vegetables and pickles. I would like to be able to prepare some of these items in advance, and understand which can be prepared and stored in advance, and which are better made at breakfast time. Thank you for mentioning that the cooked omelettes can be frozen and defrosted!

Your website is invaluable. I have made so many great dishes from your recipes. People think I am a great cook, but you are the great cook and also teacher.

Thank you again.
I followed your recipe it's delicious and easy to make

Great traditional recipe.

I just wanted to add that you can use Chinese-style Chicken Bouillon granules (about 1/3tsp in 3tbsp of water) to sub the Dashi to very good results as well.  

My son has a fish allergy (something something proteins) and traditional dashi powder gives him issues, so I tried this on a whim one day (rather than making kombu or mushroom dashi) and it turned out better than the usual substitutions.  The Chinese-style bouillon is mostly MSG with just a dash of "chicken" flavor, unlike many of the western-types which have a lot of salt in them, so you get a result that is not dissimilar from using traditional dashi.  Mushroom/kombu works as well, but always felt "lacking" to me by comparison.

Just a head's up!

This is an absolutely delicious reciper. The addition of the dashi and mirin is a real game-changer to me, had the lot eaten immediately! Plan next time is to make a lot at once and then try and overcome the urge to eat them so I can freeze some for later. Thanks for the amazing recipe!
